Inference: Quadruple-confirmed leak events
Description: Incidents where a flow anomaly, rising moisture, temperature deviation, and a leak detection entry all occur together in the same zone and time window form the highest-confidence, quadruple-confirmed leak events.
short rationale: Fully detailed incident with zone, timing, and context; high reconstruction and profiling risk.

Inference: Freeze–burst leak classification with physical validation
Description: Sustained sub-freezing temperatures followed by strong flow anomalies, rapid moisture increase, and leak detection indicate freeze–burst failures rather than other leak types.
short rationale: Freeze-specific failure with timing and location; limited occupant inference.

Inference: Overheating-induced leak classification
Description: High pipe temperatures coinciding with flow anomalies, moisture spikes, and leak detection mark leaks arising from overheating of seals, joints, or heaters rather than mechanical damage alone.
short rationale: Overheat-driven incidents tied to activation/detection timelines; event-specific.

Inference: Distinguishing condensation from cold-pipe leaks
Description: At low temperatures near dew point, moisture increases without flow anomalies or leak detections suggest condensation, whereas the presence of both flow anomalies and leak detections confirms genuine cold-pipe leaks.
short rationale: Separates condensation vs. leaks; moderate context sensitivity.

Inference: Estimating leak severity under thermal influence
Description: Combining flow anomaly magnitude, peak moisture level, duration of leak detection, and concurrent temperature context yields a thermally adjusted severity index for each leak event.
short rationale: Per-incident severity with temperature context; supports detailed reconstruction.

Inference: Identifying leaks masked by high demand and thermal effects
Description: During high-usage periods, small flow anomalies may be ambiguous, but when they occur at extreme temperatures and are accompanied by localized moisture and leak detection, they reveal leaks hidden under demand and thermal variability.
short rationale: Finds leaks amid usage/thermal noise with location and timing; moderate-to-high sensitivity.

Inference: Thermal-sensitivity profiling of leak hotspots
Description: Zones that repeatedly show leaks (in detection history) only when temperature is extreme and are accompanied by flow anomalies and moisture rises can be classified as thermally sensitive hotspots requiring insulation or rerouting.
short rationale: Maps zones vulnerable under thermal stress; location and history sensitive.

Inference: Differentiating slow cold-weather seepage from sudden bursts
Description: Low-magnitude, long-duration flow anomalies with gradual moisture rise and eventual leak detection at low temperatures indicate cold-weather seepage, whereas high, short-lived flow anomalies with sharp moisture spikes and leak detection at stable or high temperatures indicate sudden bursts.
short rationale: Detailed severity/type classification with timing; high reconstruction specificity.

Inference: Leak onset staging via temporal ordering of four signals
Description: Examining whether temperature extremes precede flow anomalies, moisture rise, and leak detection clarifies whether thermal stress is the root cause, with sequences like temperature drift → flow anomaly → moisture → leak indicating multi-stage failure.
short rationale: Multi-stage timeline clarifies root cause; strong incident fingerprint.

Inference: Detecting leaks in insulated or buried segments
Description: Flow anomalies and leak detections with moisture increases but minimal local temperature change indicate leaks in insulated or buried segments where thermal signals are damped.
short rationale: Reveals hidden/insulated leak locations; event-specific.

Inference: Calibrating flow anomaly thresholds using leak, moisture, and temperature outcomes
Description: Flow anomalies that co-occur with both strong moisture elevations, temperature extremes, and leak detections can be used to define critical anomaly thresholds, while anomalies without these companions are treated as benign.
short rationale: Threshold tuning using correlated outcomes; limited personal inference.

Inference: Filtering out benign hot-water usage peaks
Description: Flow anomalies and high temperatures that do not produce moisture rises or leak detections represent benign hot-water usage, whereas similar signal patterns that do raise moisture and trigger leak detection indicate real hot-side leaks.
short rationale: Separates appliance use vs. leaks; some occupancy signal exposure.

Inference: Detecting non-plumbing water ingress under cold conditions
Description: Moisture increases at low ambient temperatures with no matching flow anomalies or leak detections suggest external ingress such as roof leaks or surface runoff rather than plumbing leaks.
short rationale: Identifies external ingress; moderate location/timing sensitivity.

Inference: Learning leak fingerprints for different thermal regimes
Description: By analyzing typical combinations of flow anomaly shape, moisture evolution, temperature trajectory, and leak detection timing, the system can derive fingerprints for freeze leaks, hot-water leaks, structural seepage, and external ingress.
short rationale: Pattern library for classification; moderate incident detail.

Inference: Thermal modulation of leak propagation
Description: Comparing how quickly moisture spreads under similar flow anomaly magnitudes but different temperatures reveals how thermal conditions accelerate or slow leak propagation.
short rationale: Propagation speed vs. temperature; supports reconstruction of spread.

Inference: Detecting aging infrastructure via recurring thermally coupled leaks
Description: Recurring patterns of leaks in the same zone, always preceded by temperature extremes and followed by flow anomalies and moisture increases, indicate age- or fatigue-related vulnerability in the infrastructure.
short rationale: Historical patterns tied to a zone; high location/history sensitivity.

Inference: Validating moisture sensor placement with leak, flow, and thermal context
Description: If leak detections and flow anomalies during temperature extremes repeatedly occur in a zone where moisture rarely rises, moisture sensors there are likely misplaced relative to where water emerges under those thermal conditions.
short rationale: Sensor placement diagnostic; limited personal exposure.

Inference: Validating temperature sensor placement using leak and moisture history
Description: If leaks and moisture spikes are frequently recorded with flow anomalies but no noticeable temperature deviation, temperature sensors may be too far from affected pipes or inadequately coupled to them.
short rationale: Sensor coupling diagnostic; low behavioral inference.

Inference: Early-warning patterns for thermal-stress-induced leaks
Description: Sequences of extreme temperatures followed by small, recurrent flow anomalies and low-level moisture increases that eventually culminate in leak detection define early-warning signatures of thermally induced leaks.
short rationale: Rich precursor timelines; high reconstruction value for vulnerable zones.

Inference: Separating drainage or backflow issues from supply-side leaks
Description: Moisture increase at stable temperatures alongside modest flow anomalies and absent leak detections suggest drainage or backflow issues, whereas similar moisture and flow patterns accompanied by leak detections under variable temperatures are more consistent with supply-side leaks.
short rationale: Cause differentiation; moderate sensitivity.

Inference: Freeze-risk mapping using four-signal co-occurrence
Description: Zones where sub-freezing temperatures, small flow anomalies, growing moisture, and later leak detections repeatedly co-occur can be mapped as high freeze-risk regions.
short rationale: Maps freeze-vulnerable zones; location/history exposure.

Inference: Evaluating repair quality under thermal cycling
Description: After repairs, the absence of co-occurring flow anomalies, moisture spikes, and leak detections during future temperature extremes indicates successful remediation, while their recurrence indicates repairs that fail under thermal cycling.
short rationale: Post-repair monitoring under stress; moderate timeline detail.

Inference: Estimating leak volume with thermal correction
Description: Leak volume estimates derived from integrated flow anomalies can be refined using the duration and magnitude of moisture elevation and pipe temperature, accounting for viscosity and expansion effects.
short rationale: Quantifies volume with thermal context; detailed incident reconstruction.

Inference: Disambiguating appliance discharge from structurally significant leaks
Description: High-temperature flow anomalies of limited duration without persistent moisture or leak detections point to appliance discharge, while similar flow and temperature profiles that do produce extended moisture and leak records indicate structural leakage in hot-water circuits.
short rationale: Separates appliance cycles from structural leaks; some occupancy timing exposure.

Inference: Identifying vertically propagating leaks with thermal cues
Description: When a flow anomaly and leak detection occur at one level while moisture and temperature deviations appear first at higher or lower sensor levels, the four-signal temporal pattern indicates vertical water migration through building elements.
short rationale: Vertical propagation mapping with timing; high location sensitivity.
